A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

Until 1990, Uzbekistan’s health indicators on women and children were better than the 
2. 
average of the Central Asian republics. However, the situation has changed since then—a result 
of  stagnating  and  in  some  cases  deteriorating  health  indicators.  The  maternal  mortality  ratio

communicable diseases is increasing; HIV/AIDS4 registered cases have almost doubled in the 
past  2  years,  and  tuberculosis  incidence  has  doubled  over  the  past  decade.  If  this  trend 
continues, then Uzbekistan will be unable to achieve the health related millennium development

Many official health outcome statistics reported for the country may be inconsistent with 
3. 
those  obtained  through  household  surveys.  Overall,  Uzbekistan  reports  good  health  care 
coverage but quality is still lacking: about 95% of women receive antenatal care, but only 39% 
of these receive antenatal care within the first trimester of pregnancy. Moreover, 98% of women 
deliver their babies at health facilities under the guidance of a skilled health attendant, but the 
primary  cause  of  maternal  mortality  is  from  pregnancy  or  delivery  complications,  mainly 
hemorrhage  and  hypertensive  disorders.  This  evidence  suggests  that  prenatal  care  is  poor, 
despite high attendance, and that high-risk cases are poorly managed.  
  
4. 
Key Issues. Causes of poor health outcomes include (i) outdated policy, protocols, and 
procedures;  (ii)  poor  integration  of  the  health  delivery  system,  including  primary  health  care 
(PHC) (the Soviet era emphasized vertical and hospital-based health care); (iii) lack of strategic 
needs-based  human  resource  planning,  and  of  continuing  education  for  medical  and 
paramedical  staff  (the  Soviet  era  medical  system  encouraged  specialized  medical  personnel 
over  generalists,  and  institutionalized  continuing  education  programs  were  absent);  (iv) 
inequitable budgetary support and inappropriate payment systems (in Soviet times, health care 
resources were allocated through general revenues, but since independence, the resource base 
has declined drastically, and oblasts and rayons are expected to cover recurrent costs, with no 
change in budgeting systems [they are currently input based], leading to significant inequities); 
and (v) weak initiatives for dissemination of knowledge and behavioral change (health education 
was  not  traditionally  part  of  the  Soviet  health  system,  where  health  providers  did  not  inform 
patients of their health condition or services offered).  
 
5. 
Health Sector Policy Reform. The Government has embarked on several health-sector 
reform  initiatives,  since  the  mid-1990s.  In  1996,  a  Presidential  Decree  (UP-2107),  improving 
PHC for the rural population was introduced. In 1988, a comprehensive reform agenda, which 
introduced  emergency  hospitals  and  initiatives  on  the  public-private  mix  for  secondary  health 
services,  was  adopted  to  improve  equity  in  access  to  quality  and  affordable  health  care. 
Through  these  initiatives,  several  efficiency  gains  were  achieved,  including  closing  hospital 
beds, reducing hospital admissions, and improving outpatient care. A series of long-term state 
programs for woman and child health (WCH), including the integrated management of childhood 
illnesses,  the  safe  motherhood  initiative,  promotion  of  breastfeeding,  micronutrient  deficiency 
control  (primarily  iron  and  iodine),  and  family  planning  were  endorsed  in  2002.  These  were 
important steps to improve WCH. However, many programs were limited in terms of geographic 
coverage,  and  budget;  they  lacked  integration  and  were  supported  solely  by  international 
agencies.  Overall,  the  country  is  making  progress  in  improving  health  care  for  the  population, 
but considerable effort is required to accelerate reforms.  
 
6. 
Aid  Harmonization.  The  World  Bank,  active  in  the  health  sector  in  the  country  since 
1998,  has  been  supporting  the  Government’s  PHC  initiative  in  selected  oblasts  under  the 
Health-I  Project  implemented  between  1998  and  2004.  Under  the  Health-II  project,  the  World 
Bank plans to extend its support for the PHC initiative to the rest of the country, and support the 
Government’s health sector reforms related to PHC. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) and 
the  World  Bank  agreed  with  the  Ministry  of  Health  (MOH)  to  develop  parallel  and 
complementary  projects.  Both  projects  will  concentrate  on  the  primary  level.  In  addition,  the 
WCHDP  will  address  gaps  in  WCH  care  by  focusing  on  policy  reform,  providing  an  essential 
health care package, streamlining and integrating the health system, strengthening the capacity 
of  institutions  to  deliver  efficiently,  and  strengthening  the  capacity  of  health  care  providers  to 
provide quality and cost-effective interventions for WCH services.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

7. 
Woman and Child Health Care Initiatives. WCH services are currently fragmented and 
particularly limited at the Selski Vrachebny Punkt  (SVP or Russian terminology for rural medical 
center)  level.  Little  rationalization  has  taken  place  in  PHC  beyond  the  first  level  of  outpatient 
care. SVPs are the first clinics providing PHC services. For women, although pre- and postnatal 
care  as  well  as  counseling  is  provided  at  SVPs  and  policlinics,  obstetrical  care  takes  place  at 
hospitals.  The  central  rayon  hospitals  (CRHs)  provide  obstetrical  care  and  first  level  referral 
care,  although  no  referral  links  are  created  from  SVPs.  Delivery  hospitals  offer  services  for 
normal deliveries, but have little scope for care of complicated deliveries and high-risk neonates, 
and  limited  exposure  to  safe  motherhood  and  baby  friendly  hospital  initiatives.  In  addition, 
standards, guidelines, and protocols of service delivery are outdated. The oblast or next referral 
hospitals  accommodate  delivery  complications,  although  referral  protocols  remain weak.  WCH 
care rationalization and a service integration plan are needed within a health system framework. 
WCH receives little external support, and the Government has requested the assistance of the 
WCHDP in this area. 
 
8. 
Primary  Health  Care  Initiatives.  Uzbekistan  inherited  a  comprehensive  network  of 
health  care  facilities,  with  an  eight-tiered  health  delivery  system  that  overemphasized  vertical, 
hospital-based health care, and gave little priority to PHC. Under the 1996 presidential decree, 
the  Government  supported  PHC  initiatives  and  created  a  nationwide  system,  where  the  lower 
level  health  clinics  were  merged  to  form  SVPs,  staffed  with  general  medical  practitioners  and 
nurses,  and  equipped  for  preventive  and  basic  health  care  services.  Health-I  strengthened 
services  for  the  SVPs  in  three  oblasts,  and  later  this  was  extended  to  two  additional  oblasts. 
There is a need for the SVP services to be strengthened nationwide.  
 
9. 
HIV/AIDS  Initiatives.  A  comprehensive  blood  safety  program  does  not  exist.  The 
country  lacks  a  defined  national  blood  safety  policy,  strategic  planning,  and  appropriate 
legislation  and  regulations.  It  also  does  not  have  a  national  quality  management  system  or 
standards of practice for the blood supply chain. Only about 60% of blood is said to be screened 
for  blood-borne  infectious  disease  before  transfusion,  leading  to  risk  of  transmission  of 
infectious  disease  such  as  HIV/AIDS.  Many  blood  donors  are  still  subject  to  old  standards, 
guidelines,  and  protocols,  which  do  not  follow  evidence-based  medicine.  Given  Uzbekistan’s 
widely  dispersed  population,  and  the  fact  that  the  foremost  cause  of  maternal  deaths  is 
postpartum  bleeding,  having  an  adequate  and  readily  accessible  blood  supply  at  the  point  of 
need  is  a  top  priority.  The  current  blood  transfusion  supply  system  is  too  elaborate;  is  under-
funded;  and  lacks  quality  standards,  training,  and  supplies.  In  addition,  the  country  lacks  a 
reliable  and  healthy  blood  donor  base  and  registry.  The  Government  has  requested  the 
assistance of the WCHDP to establish a blood safety program in the country.

11.

the mid-1990s (from 4.6% in 1995 to 2.7% in 2002). 8 Although public sector health expenditure

resulted in acute deficits in nonsalary recurrent budgets.  
 
12.

of poverty spent less per capita on health care than richer regions. A recent study indicates that 
the poorest income quintile spent about 22% of household consumption on health care, while it 
received just under 15% of the benefits of public spending, whereas, the highest income quintile 
received  about  30%  of  the  benefits  of  public  spending.10  Pooling  resources  at  the  oblast  level 
has the potential to improve equity in spending.

health  providers  remain  among  the  lowest  in  the  country.  In  the  health  sector,  staff-related 
spending  as  a  proportion  of  recurrent  expenditures  accounts  for  more  than  70%  of  spending, 
while in primary level facilities the proportion is more than 80%. Assessments show that facilities 
need renovation, drugs are in short supply, equipment is outdated, and supplies are lacking. 
 
13. 
Despite  the  reform  agenda,  which  aims  at  developing  PHC,  76%  of  the  republican 
budget and 65% of the local budget go to hospitals (2003). For hospitals, a prospective payment 
method  is  used,  based  on  historical  patterns,  and  reimbursements  are  not  adjusted  for  case 
mix.  For  outpatient  services,  a  lump-sum  payment  mechanism  is  used  for  patient  visits. 
However, specialized diagnostic tests, such as ultrasound, are paid through direct user charges. 
Little  information  is  available  to  show  how  much  is  allocated  for  public  health  programs. 
Generally, PHC services have no formal fees at public sector health facilities. However, informal 
payment for health care is prevalent in Uzbekistan.11 One household survey suggested that 11–
30% of those seeking medical consultation paid for the services. The poor paid more frequently; 
70%  of  those  among  the  lowest  income  quintile  paid  for  health  care.  In  addition,  the  poorest 
income quintile reported spending about 22% of household consumption on health care. 
 
14. 
Health Infrastructure. WCH care has traditionally been located in the secondary health 
care  facilities.  In  rural  areas,  the  network  of  health  facilities  include  (i) midwifery  clinics  as  the 
first  contact  level  with  very  basic  primary  health  care  (PHC);  (ii)  polyclinics  as  the  second 
contact  with  additional  PHC  services;  and  (iii)  district-hospitals  and  maternity  homes,  which 
provide basic secondary health care and basic maternity and delivery care. In the urban areas, 
polyclinics are the first level of contact, and provide secondary level of care. The specialists in 
pediatrics, obstetrics, internal medicine and dentistry are housed in these polyclinics. The recent 
introduction of rural doctoral points as the first entry point instead of midwifery clinics will provide 
PHC diagnostics, basic treatment, infectious diseases prevention, and basic reproductive health 
care.  In  1997,  specialized  hospitals  were  introduced  to  deal  with  tuberculosis  and  sexually 
transmitted  diseases.  The  Government  set  up  and  strengthened  the  emergency  health  care 
facilities throughout the country. Tertiary or specialized hospitals are mostly concentrated in the 
urban cities.

16. 
Uzbekistan closed many unused hospital beds over the past decade. The country had 6 
hospital  beds  per  1,000  people  in  2000,  as  compared  with  12  per  1,000  a  decade  ago.  The 
rates are now closer to that of Greece and Italy. Since 1989, several hospital beds were closed 
because  of  low  bed  occupancy  rate  and  the  shift  to  day-care  services.  Because  budgets  are 
input-based,  this  rationalization  has  resulted  in  hospital  budgets  decreasing  by  almost  50%. 
According to a simulation, if hospital beds are currently at 165,000, and inpatient admission rate 
is  at  0.13%,  then  the  bed  occupancy  rate  is  at  75%.  According  to  some  reports,  the  bed 
occupancy rate averages about 50–60%, and in many hospitals, as few as 20% beds may be 
occupied. Thus several more unused beds could be closed, and perhaps facilities merged, on 
basis of economies of scale. However, this may be a politically sensitive subject, and unless the 
budgetary  process  changes  from  input-  to  output  based,  there  will  be  little  incentive  to  close 
down hospital beds. 
 
Health Personnel. The country has about three doctors per 1,000 people; less than 1% 
17. 
work  in  the  private  sector.  Most  physicians  are  specialists;  in  the  former  Soviet  system  little 
emphasis  was  given  to  general  practitioners.  The  doctor-to-population  ratio  in  Uzbekistan  is 
higher than the average of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (2.8), 
which  faces  a  higher  burden  of  noncommunicable  diseases  that  require  specialized  care. 
Uzbekistan rates are closer to that of Australia and Finland. In 1995, the Government introduced 
a licensing system, and only licensed physicians are permitted to practice in the private sector. 
Fewer than about 1% of physicians are expected to be in the private sector. The new policy on 
privatizing  the  provision  of  health  care  and  introducing  fees  for  health  services  raise  greater 
concerns about equity and access. 
 
18. 
For the WCH program, the Government employs about 6,000 obstetricians (or 0.24 per 
1,000 population), 20,000 midwives (0.8 per 1,000 population), and 12,000 pediatricians (or 0.5 
per  1,000  population)  in  2001.  In  1999,  the  Government  created  a  post  of  general  practice 
physicians for PHC facilities, and offered a program of postgraduate training of general practice 
physicians  at  medical  schools.  These  physicians  are  supposed  to  work  at  the  rural  doctoral 
points,  and  provide  preventive  and  basic  curative  health  care  to  all  patients,  including  women 
and  children.  The  specialists,  placed  at  the  secondary  or  rayon  hospitals,  provide  referral 
support  for  PHC,  and  conduct  delivery  and  postnatal  care  for  women  and  neonatal  care  for 
children.  The  specialists  at  tertiary  or  oblast  hospitals  provide  referral  support  to  secondary 
health facilities, and supervise staff in the lower level health facilities. However, supervision of 
recently trained physicians working in these newly created positions and newly developed rural 
doctoral  points  is  problematic—their  supervisors  are  specialists  who work  in  the  higher  levels, 
and who have received little training and work in the older less developed health facilities. 
 
19. 
In addition, Uzbekistan has about 10 nurses per 1,000 population. The average ratio of 
nurse-to-population  in  the  Organization  for  Economic  Cooperation  and  Development  is  about 
7.5.  The  Government  aims  to  keep  the  ratio  of  physicians  to  nurses  at  1  to  7.  To  accomplish 
this,  they  recently  reduced  the  admission  rates  to  medical  colleges,  and  simultaneously 
increased the admission rates to nursing colleges. At this point, many nurses are employed in 
the system; many are redundant. The quality of nursing programs is outdated and is in question.

B.  Poverty Analysis  
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
A  specific  poverty  analysis  is  not  required.  The  Living  Standards  Assessment  was  conducted  in  2002,  and  the 
Demographic Health Survey will provide results in 2003. These surveys provide data for further analysis in this section.  
In  Uzbekistan,  overall,  27%  of  the  population  lives  below  poverty  line,  with  almost  69%  of  the  poor  living  in  rural 
areas.  Past  data  are  not  comparable,  but  the  1996  household  poverty  incidence  is  estimated  at  21%.  The  southern 
region,  Kashkadarya  and  Sukhandarya,  reported  the  worst  poverty  incidence,  followed  by  the  northern  region, 
Karakalpakstan  and  Khorezm;  together  these  regions  comprise  28%  of  the  country’s  population,  but  over  55%  of  the 
share of poor and extremely poor. Kashkadarya oblast reported the worst incidence of poverty and extreme poverty in 
the country.  

Poverty Classification:  Poverty Intervention 

Some health indicators are influenced by poverty. Poorer income groups are less likely to seek health care. While 
almost  55%  of  individuals  in  the  highest  income  quartile  sought  health  care,  only  44%  in  the  lowest  income  quartile 
sought health  care. The higher income  groups are more likely to use secondary/tertiary  health facilities relative to the 
lower income groups, which rely more on outpatient centers and clinics. Individuals from the lowest income groups rely 
most  heavily  on  primary  health  care  (PHC)  facilities.  The  higher  income  groups  are  30–50%  more  likely  to  go  to  the 
central raion  polyclinic or hospital or the city polyclinic or hospital, are more likely to be admitted to hospitals, and have 
longer hospital stays. (Family Income and Expenditure Survey, 1996; World Bank. 2002. Uzbekistan, Living Standards 
Assessment:  Health,  Nutrition,  and  Population.  Washington,  DC;  Cashin,  C.  2001.  Access  to  Health  Care  in  Rural 
Fergana Oblast, Uzbekistan. Study prepared by ZdravPlus, USAID, Tashkent). 
        The Project will have a poverty intervention focus. The project sites will be selected using the following criteria: (i) 
poverty profile, (ii) poor maternal mortality and anemia, (iii) poor infant mortality and malnutrition, (iv) high incidence of 
tuberculosis, and (v) poor access to water. Based on these selection criteria, the oblasts of focus have tentatively been 
identified as Bukhara, Karakalpakstan, Khorezm, Kashkadarya, and Tashkent (does not include Tashkent city).

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

1. 
Public  intervention  in  the  health  sector  typically  has  a  number  of  justifications:  public 
goods, positive externalities, and merit goods. A limited number of health goods are technically 
“public” goods,1 where the marginal cost of providing services to an additional person is zero or 
near zero. Services that have positive externalities2 should generally be provided at low or zero 
cost  to  patients  either  through  direct  service  provision  or  demand-side  subsidies.  Merit  good3 
justification  is  strengthened  when  technical  information  about  services  is  complex  or  where 
substantial  counter-information  pushes  consumers  toward  the  wrong  choices.  This  Project  is 
justified on grounds that it will provide services that have (i) positive externalities, given that it 
will focus on primary health care (PHC) and will address issues of family planning; and (ii) merit 
goods as it will directly impact woman and child health (WCH), through antenatal care and care 
of  sick  children,  reduce  unnecessary  use  of  hospitals,  and  provide  better  information  to 
consumers.  
 
2. 
For the economic analysis of the Project, costs (financial and non-financial) and benefits 
(mainly  health)  of  the  Project  are  examined.  These  include  (i)  reduced  travel  time  from 
treatments PHC facilities; and (ii) reduced opportunity cost of patient care resulting from shorter 
stays  in  hospital.  Computing  these  likely  benefits  has  not  been  possible.  However,  their 
inclusion would improve the following highlighted cost-effectiveness ratios.

The key outcomes of interest are the infant mortality rate (IMR) and  maternal mortality 
ratio  (MMR).  The  problem  with  MMR  is  that  it  is  such  a  rare  event  that  it  requires  a  large 
population just to measure accurately let alone show a significant impact from an intervention.4 
In contrast, a much smaller population is required to measure and show a significant effect on 
the IMR.5 Given this increased reliability we focus on the impact of project inputs on the IMR. 
Process indicators that are thought to be highly correlated with MMR include skilled attendance 
at birth and improved access to comprehensive obstetric facilities.

FOR WOMAN AND CHILD HEALTH DEVELOPMENT 

Objective 

Scope and Methodology 

 
A. 
 
1. 
The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  (i)  strengthen  the  capacity  of  the  Ministry  of  Health 
(MOH)  to  deal  with  health  issues  by  improving  its  understanding  of  provider  and  consumer 
behaviors,  and  of  causes  of  morbidity  and  mortality;  (ii)  help  the  Government  to  rationalize 
services  for  woman  and  child  health  care;  and  (iii)  increase  the  effectiveness  and  delivery  of 
services  through  quality  monitoring  and  improvements.  The  TA  complements  the  Project  by 
strengthening  MOH  capacity  to  address  woman  and  child  health  care  service  delivery  more 
efficiently and effectively and to sustain its development. 
 
B. 
 
2. 
The  TA  has  three  components:  (i)  a  study  to  understand  the  causes  of  child  (under-5 
years) mortality, (ii) an optimization exercise to rationalize and integrate the health care delivery 
system, and (iii) a strategy to improve information base for quality monitoring.  
 
3. 
Limited data is available on causes of infant (first year of life) or childhood (years 1–5) 
mortality  in  Uzbekistan  and  virtually  all  available  data  is  based  on  passive  reporting  via  the 
death  certificate  registration.  Current  data  reports  exaggerated  levels  of  death  due  to  acute 
respiratory  infection  largely  because  physicians  did  not  know  the  cause  of  death  and  use  this 
category as a convenient catchall. Child mortality causes are not well known either because of 
insufficient  diagnostic  skills  or  testing  facilities,  or  because  health  providers  are  discouraged 
from reporting the actual cause. Many underreported neonatal deaths are believed to be due to 
asphyxia  or  prematurity  that  is  misclassified  when  cause  of  death  is  given.  To  date,  little  is 
known about actual causes of death. The TA will conduct a verbal autopsy study (retrospective 
mortality  cases  will  be  followed  through  to  asses  cause  of  death),  and  the  results  will  help 
identify  the  true  causes  of  death,  help  gain  information  for  evidence-based  medicine,  and 
identify training needs for health providers. 
 
A  fundamental  issue  to  be  addressed  in  undertaking  optimization  is  the  change  in  the 
4. 
numbers  and  mix  of  health  services  and  staff.  While  incentives  provided  through  payment 
systems  act  to  encourage  efficiency,  a  coordinated  plan  for  human  resources  that  is  not 
confined to a single facility or area is needed. Up to now human resource planning has occurred 
mainly within rayons, where staff have shifted from hospital to primary care facilities. A variety of 
other options are available to address both excess staffing and lack of the appropriate skill mix 
including  early  retirement,  retraining,  redundancy  with  help  in  getting  alternative  employment, 
and  transfer  to  other  institutions.  Developing  oblast  plans  would  be  a  first  stage  to  adopting a 
coordinated strategy for optimizing services and developing a human resources strategy. These 
plans should be linked to plans for training new medical staff, so that the output of medical and 
nursing colleges is related to the demand for staff within the health system. The TA will conduct 
a study on optimization of health services, and on human resources in the health sector. This 
will help to develop a national strategy for financing a smooth transition from current staffing and 
skill  levels  to  those  required  in  a  more  efficient  system.  The  study  will  analyze  the  expected 
future  supply  of  different  types  of  staffing  cadres  and  skills  under  current  levels  of  natural 
attrition and training outputs of medical schools, colleges, and institutes. It will also examine the 
demand for staffing based on the skills and levels required to deliver good quality woman and 
child-care  and  other  essential  care  and  other  services,  using  updated  protocols.  Finally,  the 
strategy  would  examine  how  to  bring  supply  and  demand  for  human  resources  into  balance

incentives, and redundancy issues including costs. 
 
5. 
While a lot of information is collected, much of its value is lost because managers do not 
use it for analysis and decision-making. Throughout Uzbekistan, heads of hospitals, clinics, and 
health administration offices are doctors who have been assigned managerial responsibility but 
have little or no training to help them carry out their duties. Many managers see themselves first 
as  doctors  and  secondly  as  mere  custodians.  Few  see  themselves  as  proactive  decision 
makers. Recently, in part because of various reform initiatives now under way, managers within 
the  health  system  are  beginning  to  realize  the  potential  of  information  to  help  them  plan  and 
manage  their  organizations.  The  TA  will  help  develop  an  information  system  strategy  for  the 
health sector, which will provide timely and reliable data.
